body_html:
@soumith TL;DR - I would probably agree. It does not make sense to encourage everyone publishing a novel method to shove their code into pytorch.

I am first author on the paper but will try to produce a balanced response.

I believe that the paper provides strong evidence that this method can provide benefits over existing approaches, e.g., classical momentum. It also shows that this has it's place even compared to adaptive methods, e.g., adam. Of course, I would much rather people read the paper themselves and decide whether they agree with these statements. And to try and answer your final question - I think it is too hard to say. We found that Nesterov momentum works very well but yet it seems to see relatively little use in practice.

My motivation for creating the pull request (excluding the more obvious and self-serving) is to encourage reproducibility. Making the barrier-to-entry as low as possible is an obvious advantage for new science and pytorch seems like a good way to achieve this. However, I understand that this may not align with your goals in this case.

Finally, as an optimization tool this seems to be relatively standalone. I would imagine this makes maintenance a little easier but I am not a core pytorch dev and would certainly trust your experience over my opinions.
